acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 48 hours EC50=6.77mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (SIDS (2003) and others.).

acute_toxicity_dermal.hazard_statement: May be harmful in contact with skin
acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rabbit LD50 (dermal route) value of 2,990mg/kg (PATTY (4th, 1999)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 1,160mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 2,980mg/kg, 6,400mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 2001-61 (2002)), 1,160mg/kg and 1,450mg/kg (PATTY (4th, 1999)).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity was Category 2 and the bio-accumulation potential was low (BCF=8.1(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 4%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Category 2.

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flash point is 93degC (open cup flash test) (ICSC (1999)), which is classified into Category 4.

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to the insufficiency of data (no data available on in vivo mutagenicity/genotoxicity tests)

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of adverse effects on reproduction and development (reduced number of implantation sites/litters) at doses causing parental toxicity, described in SIDS (2003), MOE Risk Assessment vol. 4 (2005) and the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (1997).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (SIDS (2003)): "moderately irritating." The substance is thus considered to possess a potential for strong irritation of the eye.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (4-hour application) (SIDS (2003)): "Draize scores for 24, 48, and 72 hours: Erythema = 1.83, Edema = 0.22 and PII = 2.08" and "moderate irritation."

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver, kidney)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "the substance may adversely affect the liver and kidneys" (ICSC (J) (1997)) and the evidence from animal studies including "regeneration of the renal tubular epithelium and granular cast formation, along with mild periportal fat degeneration" (SIDS (2002)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
